--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> :) I haven't had chance to do the thorough P.I. job
> you seem to be doing 
> Derek but from what you've said it all sounds a bit
> odd. 

I guess I didn't do *that* thorough a job...I didn't
find his papers. :)

> Exactly how can 
> someone patent Hebbian learning anyway? Aren't
> patents  supposed to 
> contain/define something that is unique and distinct
> from what has been 
> done before. 

Well, they *should* be, but I've heard quite a bit of
cirticism of our patenting procedures (e.g., the U.S.
Patent Office has apparently issued patents for how to
make toast and techniques for swinging on playground
swings).

> Nothing wrong with a healthy dose of skepticism, it
> is the basis of 
> scientific discovery after all. I suspect you may be
> jumping the gun 
> though, I'm sure he's a thouroughly nice chap.

I don't know how *nice* he is, but maybe you're right.
 At least there are some references for his
credentials.  He does use very broad, grandiose
rhetoric regarding neural networks (e.g., he calls
neural networks "brains", "The brains will be trained
to solve a famous engineering problem: balancing an
inverted pendulum.").  I suppose he does so in order
to try to impress prospective investors.

Fair enough.  

Derek
